title: How does one explain that freedom of speech is not freedom from consequence? - Quora

response.answer_text: The original link attached to this question no longer works. Nevertheless, a similar statement was tweeted by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. There is certainly something to be said that some kinds of speech should definitely have consequences. The issue surrounding the statement; however, is that people fail to apply it evenhandedly. In fact, sometimes the consequences aren’t even about what was said — they arise because of the person saying it and the political party he or she appears to represent. Cortez tweeted her statement about Congressman Steve King (R-IA) who she accuses of racism. But she also entirely ignores Biden’s seemingly racist statements and the Democratic Party, and many others who identify as liberal also ignore any controversial statements made by members of their own party, but hop on the epithet spouting bandwagon whenever a conservative is accused of doing so. Robert Riedel's answer to What do you think about Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's claim that: "Freedom of speech does not mean freedom from consequences?” During a contentious interview with radio personality Charlamagne tha God on "The Breakfast Club," a popular syndicated New York radio broadcast, Biden responded to Charlemagne question about returning to the show for more questions, “If you have a problem figuring out whether you're for me or Trump, then you ain't black.” The statement was widely panned as “racist” and Biden has since tried to walk back the comments. However the treatment of Biden by his own party is in stark contrast to the way similar statements by conservatives are handled in the media. Had Trump or any Republican made a statement like that, it would have been 24-hour a day news on every media outlet, the subject of endless expert interviews reiterating over and over that the statement was racist and proof that the Whitehouse was occupied by a white supremacist. Nor is this Biden’s only gaffe. But unlike conservatives who are taken to task for every comment, the media and the Democratic Party largely ignores the foibles of their own party, or others who identify as liberal. If consequences are going to arise when exercising the freedom of expression, then everyone should be treated equally.  (Cartoon taken from the Los Angeles Daily News, [1] ) Footnotes[1] The Democrats have a Joe Biden problem: Political Cartoons

It has to do with the common misconception that freedom of speech somehow means that one is free from criticism and judgment, when it means freedom from state censorship and legal punishments. So, if someone says something idiotic, they are and should be completely free to do so, but if he gets called an idiot, than that is protected speech too. Similarly, if nowadays someone, for example, says something racist and then many people get upset and start boycotting campaigns and demanding that that person should be fired, it does not impinge on freedom of speech in any way. People are free to criticize public statements (which is everything in social media if one is not careful) and they are free to choose not to support a private company. That is freedom of expression and these are just consequences of the original utterance. Quite many complaints about free speech nowadays center on this issue. Twitter has no requirement to allow accounts that disagree with their terms of service. Facebook has no requirement either. They are private entities and can control their content. Universities can do this too. Of course people have rights that say they shoudn’t be judged due to their race, ideology or religion, but this doesn’t cover anyplace anywhere. In a nutshell, freedom of speech does not mean freedom from consequences is the same everybody learns very early in life: if you behave like an asshole, you will be treated like one.

I’ve got mixed feelings on this one. Part of American free speech is that we have developed a culture of free speech. Politically we used to respect that others could disagree with us, while we could still be friends or acknowledge that they were decent people. We seem to have gotten away from that, where many think that any disagreement from our point of view needs to be challenged and punished. I’m a basketball fan. I realize that many of the players are on the liberal side of the political spectrum. I choose to let them have their points of view while not throwing a boycott tantrum if they say something I disagree with. That said, I sympathize with those who are upset with the kneelers in the NFL who are making a scene out of what should be a unifying moment during the anthem at the start of games. If you go too far out of your way to thumb your nose at your customers, eventually they are going to have enough and stop supporting you. If you are a marginal talent (Colin Kaepernick) who causes your employer to lose revenue, it might not be worth the trouble paying your salary if I will lose fans. I was very troubled by what happened after Prop 8 in California when donor lists were used to get people fired from a variety of employers who happened to have donated to a cause they believed in. While this was not government imposed restriction, it was very much counter to the idea that we should be able to say what we want in our private time.

Freedom of speech encompasses anything anyone says that does not lead to immediate or specific acts of violence and that are not knowingly lies intended to harm the reputation of a specific person. Those are the *only* two exceptions. You can be as profane as you like. In earlier times profanity was, on occasion, considered as an incitement to riot, but even that reading is long since gone. You can be as hateful as you like. Say terrible things. Offensive things. None of that is prohibited under freedom of speech. The proper response to bad speech is more speech, telling why it was bad. Even the old canard about not shouting fire in a crowded theater isn’t valid. In fact, the Justice who first said it took it back shortly thereafter when he saw how it was being misinterpreted. There can be legal consequences to shouting fire in a crowded theater, but not due to the speech itself. It is covered under wanton endangerment, just like driving while intoxicated or any other *act* that knowingly causes unwitting others to be put in significant danger without their consent. It would also apply to, say, someone hauling a piano up to a third floor room outside the building without first clearing out the sidewalk below or a chemist that put a dangerous chemical in an orange juice bottle and sticks it in the fridge without keeping a 100% watch on it before he takes it back out.

Any form of street talk, gutter language, intentional insults, intentional offensive words or ideas, racist bigotry, emotional outbursts, and hate speech are subject to consequences such as censorship, serious reprimands, or worse and are not protected as free speech rights. It is important to know the difference between uncivilized bad miscreant behavior and honorable freedom of speech intended for conveying ideas or opinions with intellectual context and in a civilized manner. Under the First Amendment, you have the right to use hateful words like curse words and also a right to talk about hateful ideas such as Nazi torture techniques or sexual perversions but that does not include hate speech that is racist bigotry. Under international human rights, every person from the day of their birth possess the right to freedom of speech that applies at all times and in all places, in public and private, in government and business, online and the workplace. In a democratic society, your free speech rights are also protected from consequences, threats, and coercion in order to guarantee that the speaker is expressing his true honest opinions without adjustment for threats.

Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks once stated that she was ashamed to admit Bush was from Texas. She was perfectly within her rights to say so. Some people disagreed with her. Bush stated she was entitled to her opinion and left it at that. This did NOT mean that those who disagreed with her HAD to buy Dixie Chicks albums, or that they couldn't destroy the ones they already had. The fact that there COULD be consequences is what makes freedom of speech meaningful. This ensures we use our freedoms responsibly. If you aren't willing to let the chips fall where they may, perhaps you should say nothing.

Let’s test this. Let’s take you, your house, your partner. I, a popular blogger with a huge following of fat bastards with semi automatic second amendment protectors, for reasons of my own, declare that YOUR cellar is used in secret pedophile orgies. Your partner gets shot. Accidentally. By “a concerned citizen” (you guessed it, a white dude). And my many fans agree that your house not having a cellar is clear proof of something dodgy going on. Oh and your dead partner is obviously an actor/actress who just played dead. And you of course get death threats for the rest of your partnerless life. Who do you, leader of a non existing pedophile ring, in your non existing cellar, with your not dead partner, think should be protected from consequences?

Well, here’s my attempt;  I’ve seen people on the left AND the right engage in troll logic like that. Neonazis make Youtube videos about Neonazi stuff, Kellogs takes their adds away, Neonazis call that censorship. Misandrist describes videogames innacurately, people who’ve actually played the game correct her, misandrist accuses them all of sexism. I would argue that the Neonazi Kellogs thing is NOT an attack on Free Speech, because they are no longer getting sponsored, therefore, they can say what they want for free. Innacurately describe something nerds know about and getting corrected? That’s just cause-and-effect. The distinction, however, is whether IT stops you or YOU stop you. If you touch fire and it burns you, technically the only thing stopping you from touching it again is your own fear. If an authority puts a wall between you and the fire because that’s how stupid you are, THAT is censorship. If you make a movie and the Hayz office won’t let you sell it, that’s censorship. If you make a movie and people decide for themselves not to see it, that’s consequences.

To the extent that I understand Mr. Tracy, he skirts around the law most oddly and I fear incorrectly. Insulting speech is protected while inducing violence with speech is not. He is not helped by this question, whose intent I find masked by the language used. I really, after multiple re-readings, cannot divine what the OP is trying to find out. Hope it gets edited.

Simply put, “your right to free speech ends at everybody else’s ears.” Meaning, nobody hearing you exercise your right to free speech is required to listen to you, refrain from calling you an asshole, give you a forum to exercise your right to free speech, hire you to work for them, or have anything to do with you interpersonally. The reason for this is that everybody else has freedom of speech too, as well as freedom of association.

The purpose of freedom of speech / expression is to limit / preclude the government from interfering with your ability to speak your mind, express your own ideas, and to share your thoughts and opinions with others. The exchange of ideas and public debate is positive for both individuals and society. But why should you be excused from consequences? All behavior has consequences. There’s no benefit to anyone to allow a world where one could say anything but never be held to account for it.

You should be only free of illegal consequences. If you say something and some other person boycotts your business, or fires you, that is on you. If you say something and someone else threatens you, blackmails you, fires you illegally etc, then they should be held responsible for their actions. In simple terms: Fire a nazi, ok. Punch a nazi you get charged with assault. Fire a person because they are white/male, and you get sued.

No one ever promised freedom from consequences — outside of what the state can do. The state can’t put you in jail for making an opinion public or criticizing the government. But freedom of speech laws don’t apply to your employer, your husband or wife, your neighbour or the clubs you belong to.

Freedom of speech — meaning the government won’t prosecute or fine you for what you say — is a freedom from consequences. Namely those aforementioned fines and jail times. One can’t separate the two — freedom of speech and freedom from those specific consequences.

Freedom of speech without consequences is just tyranny under the guise of freedom. The State may allow you to express your views freely without consequence but the Society won’t afford you the same protection and tolerance. Don’t get confused between the two.
